text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: When an object in a source package refers to another object in a different package a dependency exists between the two packages. Every package may, therefore, have a number of prerequisite packages that must be loaded first before it can be successfully imported into an
. Binary packages also have similar prerequisites for other binary packages.

para.style: text-align:left; text-indent:0px; margin-top:14px; margin-right:0px; margin-bottom:14px; margin-left:0px; line-height:1.46; background-color:transparent; white-space:normal; page-break-inside:auto; page-break-after:auto; border:none; tabstops:none;

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: There is a slight difference in the way prerequisites work when compared with the source package equivalent. Whereas a source package cannot be loaded until all the prerequisite packages are present, a binary package only requires that a prerequisite is loaded "on demand" when it is required at runtime. This is an important distinction, since it enables large applets to achieve faster start-up times by careful partitioning of the constituent packages.
